By MICHAEL BERKE
Chemistry Department
Chairman Robert C. Parr is
soliciting student evaluations of
six junior chemistry professors.
Parr wants the ratings to help in
selection of the Chemistry
Departinent nominee for a
foundation grant.
The nominee will be
considered for a $25,000 grant
by the Camille and Henry
Dreyfus Foundation of New
York.
Twenty to thirty nominees
will be selected nationwide by a
six -member committee of
chemistry educators to receive
the awards which will be
announced in August or
•
September.
Chemistry faculty members
under consideration for the
department's nomination are Drs.
Aaron Bloch, Peter Y. Johnson,
Luigi Marzilli, Jerome H.
Perlstein, Douglas Poland and
Gary Posner. Of the six
professors Parr said, "You can't
tell who's the best."
To be eligible for nomination,
a professor must have been on
the faculty for five years or less.

Nomination will be made by full
professors in the chemistry
department.
Teaching Methods
Grant money is to be used at
the discretion of the awardee
according to guidelines laid down
by the foundation. Possible uses
of grant money are aupport of
teaching assistants, purchase of
experimental teaching equipment
and testing new teaching
methods.
Although the grant may be
used for research or travel, Parr
said that the nominees will be
"the type of people who will not
forsake teaching."
Hopkins has nominated
professors for the grants last year
and the year before but no
faculty member has received an
award.
Members of the. all-university
nominating committee are Albert
L. Lehninger, director of the
department of physiological
chemistry at the medical school
and Roger Harriot, chairman of
the depart ment ofbiochemistry at
the school of hygiene and public
health.

The Chemistry Department's
nominee will go to an
all-university faculty committee
chaired by Parr. The committee
will select a single university
nominee from names submitted
by the chemistry and biology
departments at Homewood, the
department of physiological
chemistry at the medical school,
and the department of
biochemistry at the school of
hygiene and public health.
The all-university committee
will meet during the week of
March 2 to select the Hopkins
nominee. President Steven Muller
will convey the nomination to
the foundation.
Parr wants the student input
to strengthen the nominating
letter to the foundation. "It is
better to quote student letters in
a letter to a foundation," he said.
Parr is looking for positive
comments from students about
the quality of the six professors'
lectures, their interest in and
willingness to help students,
encouragement of class
participation and approachability
outside of class.

THE TRUTH ABOUT THE
M. GOLDSEKER LAW SUIT
The most important issue underlying the fact that the case against us in the Federal Court was dismissed several days ago is
whether or not we overcharged our customers.
Before the lawsuit was instituted against us, we publicly offered any sincere person or group the opportunity to examine our
books and records to see what profit we made. Prior to trial we volunteered to allow the plaintiffs to choose a Certified Public
Accountant of their liking to come into our office and examine our books and records. They did, and their auditors carefully
examined our accounting books, our records, cancelled checks, contracts and numerous- other documents, and after so doing
discovered within percentage points that the expenses and profit we have been quoting for several years were true. Therefore,
the conclusion had to be drawn that the M. Goldseker Company did not overcharge. Certainly no one in our position could have
done any more than we dicl in subjecting ourselves to a revealing examination of this kind, and the results speak for themselves.
By the time the trial began, a great number of the allegations in the complaint filed against our company had fallen by the
wayside. Thirty-five of the original seventy-six individual plaintiffs had dropped out of the case. At the conclusion of their
evidence, the plaintiffs even admitted they had not made out a case against us.

WE SUBMIT

that the plaintiffs after two years of litigation were unable to make out a case against us.

WE SUBMIT

that the plaintiffs did hire an appraiser and the appraiser did make appraisals for them. Why was

the appraiser withdrawn? Why was a new appraiser necessary?

WE SUBMIT

that the reason the appraiser was withdrawn was because he was unable to prove we overcharged.

WE SUBMIT

that if the plaintiffs believed they had a case against us and that a new appraiser was needed,
responsible blacks and other people and groups interested in black housing in the community could have been called upon and
certainly they would have supplied either the talent or the few hundred dollars necessary to employ another appraiser.

The persons who sued us, however, withdrew their case and the Court dismissed the complaint against us for lack of
evidence. Our sympathy lies with our few customers who were led to believe they were taken advantage of. We feel no ill will
towards them. Had those Activists who misled our customers seen fit to accept our offer to examine our books and records in
the first place, they would have discovered the truth. They were offered the same opportunity as the Plaintiffs were to choose a
Certified Public Accountant to examine our record/. Once the Activists discovered we did not overcharge anyone, they would
have found it necessary to go fram door to door and neighborhood to neighborhood in order to spread unfounded and unjust
propoganda to the public, and most importantly they could have prevented the community from being incited unnecessarily
against us and against all those who were engaged in legitimate business enterprises.
